did.unittitle: Abrabanel, Solomon. London, England, The complaint of the children of Israel, representing their grievances under the penal laws; and praying, that if the tests are repealed, the jews may have the benefit of this indulgence in common with all other subjects of England. In a letter to a reverend high priest of the church by law established. Second edition. By Solomon Abrabanel, of the house of David. London: printed for J. Webb. 1736. Solomon Abrabanel is the pseudonym of William Arnall, a non-Jewish political writer

did.unittitle: De Sola, Abraham. Montreal, Canada, The sanatory institutions of the Hebrews: as exhibited in the scriptures and Rabbinical writings, and as bearing upon modern sanatory regulations. This is an extremely rare booklet, soft bound by the famous Canadian Rabbi Abraham De Sola. It deals with the laws of Kashrut as described in the Bible as well as Rabbinical writings. De Sola also relates them to modern times. Published in Montreal by John Lovell at his steam printing establishment, 1861

Another part of the book was used by another person for an accounting ledger

did.unittitle: Levy, Benjamin. New Orleans, LA, Original waybill for transportation of ten boxes of spices taken by the steamboat "Alabama" from New Orleans to Natchez, dated December 18, 1821, signed by Samuel Rogers, Master, and George Evans. The form was printed by Benjamin Levy and Company, with a small vignette of ships at sea. This is one of the earliest examples of Benjamin Levy's printing

did.unittitle: Levy, Charles. Breckenridge, CO, A coupon folder from the Charles Levy store of Breckenridge, Colorado. did.unittitle: Dreyfus, Nathan A. New York, NY, This pamphlet is from Detroit Novelty Works.It discusses the infringment of a patent b yNathan A. Dreyus, the New York agent of the Rue Manufacturing Coo., who bought the US rights for the supplementary jet injector from the inventor James Gresham in 1866 and then made subsequent improvements that were patented. Judge Wheeler filed his decision, fully sustaining the validity of the Patent, declaring the infringement, and directing an injunction and account. From the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineer's monthly journal, volume 14, Issue 10, 1880
